content: I would like to understand in this book by Rosicky Adamek Vitale: Algebraic Theories_ A categorical introduction to general algebra (2009), on the page 7 what do the morphisms in T\cal TT correspond to in the sense of universal algebra in the sense of Birkhoff. I understand though that SetS∗\mathbb{Set}^{S^*}SetS∗ are SSS-sorted sets, but I do not understand it for a more general T\cal TT. What are the objects and morphisms in T\cal TT send to by finite product preserving functors to SetSetSet (and correspond to) ?

The name they give to T\mathcal{T}T is algebraic theory. That name is used in universal algebra to refer to a signature Σ\SigmaΣ coupled with a set of equations between Σ\SigmaΣ-terms. So you should think of T\mathcal{T}T as describing the operations allowed in your algebras as well as their constraints. It can be difficult to see how exactly these are represented in the objects and morphisms of T\mathcal{T}T.

Sometimes, people restrict their attention to theories T\mathcal{T}T which are generated by a single object, meaning the objects of T\mathcal{T}T are natural numbers and the product is addition. This makes it easier to see because a finite product preserving functor T→Set\mathcal{T} \to \mathbf{Set}T→Set will send 111 to some set AAA, and the rest will be completely determined as n=1+⋯n+1n = 1 + \stackrel{n}{\cdots} + 1n=1+⋯n​+1 means nnn is sent to A×⋯n×A=AnA \times \stackrel{n}{\cdots} \times A = A^nA×⋯n​×A=An.

Now, a morphism t:n→mt: n \to mt:n→m in T\mathcal{T}T will be interpreted as a function t:An→Amt : A^n \to A^mt:An→Am, and you should understand this as an mmm -tuple of terms with nnn variables. Indeed, ttt takes a choice of n inputs in A and computes m outputs in A, and by some properties of the product, you can check this done by mmm unrelated computations (this is not necessarily the case in monoidal theories).

When T\mathcal{T}T is not generated by a single-object it can be more complicated to see. I find it easier to think of theories as signatures with equations, but I am sure this depends on what kind of algebras you are trying to present. There are "classical" theories that are disgusting and yet present some simple things (I remember an example that I cannot find right now).

These notes by Awodey and Bauer are way more gentle than Algebraic Theories.

Now, a morphism t:n→mt: n \to mt:n→m in the theory T\mathcal{T}T will be sent to a function ⟦t⟧:An→Am\llbracket t \rrbracket : A^n \to A^m [[t]]:An→Am, and you understand this as an mmm tuple of terms with nnn variables. Indeed, ⟦t⟧\llbracket t \rrbracket[[t]] takes any assignment of nnn variables into AAA (i.e. a function n→An\to An→A) to mmm elements of AAA. So it tells you how to compute mmm different outputs out of nnn inputs from AAA. Thanks to the properties of products, you can show that these mmm different computations are unrelated so it is actually mmm different terms (this is not the case when looking at monoidal theories).

There is a missing message that could not compile for some reason, let me try again. OK kinda fixed it. But there is a sentence where I cannot put dollar signs around 'n' for some reason. It should be: ttt takes a choice of nnn inputs in AAA and computes mmm outputs in AAA
Why this compiles here but not in my earlier message I don't know.
Well now my older paragraph has reappeared without my doing anything. This is really confusing...

@Ralph Sarkis Yes, I'm aware of what you say, but my questions was exactly about what you claim that can "be more complicated to see". Could you come up with an example of a T\cal TT that would give to me a feeling what some strange morphism in T\cal TT could mean in the interpretation of T\cal TT,i.e. a functor AAA to Set\mathbb {Set}Set ? In particular T\cal TT should not be a single object generated, so try AAA and BBB generated and the interpretation of a morphism in question in it should be somehow self-explanatory for my question.

For an exemple of a simple theory, yet not generated by asingle sort, what about the theory of a ring together with a module ?
It's a theory Tmod\mathcal{T}_{\text{mod}}Tmod​ whose models are pairs (R,M)(\mathcal{R}, \mathcal{M})(R,M) of a ring R\mathcal{R}R and an R\mathcal{R}R-module M\mathcal{M}M. In terms of signature, it is generated by two sorts rrr and mmm, operations 0,1:⊤→r0,1 : \top \to r0,1:⊤→r, +,∗:(r,r)→r+,* : (r,r) \to r+,∗:(r,r)→r, ρ:(r,m)→m\rho : (r,m) \to mρ:(r,m)→m together with the ring and modules equations. I guess an explicit presentation of Tmod\mathcal{T}_{\text{mod}}Tmod​ can be worked out using freely generated rings and modules.

The simplest typical example of a T\mathcal TT that isn't generated by a single object is the theory of "A monoid and a set it acts on." This is generated under finite products by two objects, call them MMM and S.S.S. As in any finite product category with object generators the only interesting morphisms are those with codomain MMM and S.S.S. There are morphisms Mk→MM^k\to MMk→M comprising a full subcategory of T\mathcal TT isomorphic to the usual theory of monoids, while there are no morphisms Sk→SS^k\to SSk→S or Mk→SM^k\to SMk→S other than those built from product projections and diagonals. The most interesting part of the theory, then, is the class of morphisms μ:Mk×S→S\mu:M^k\times S\to Sμ:Mk×S→S which, in a model, correspond to the action on an element of SSS by kkk elements of the monoid M.M.M.

Anyway, that's my suggested example. If you feel comfortable with the categorical interpretation of single-sorted algebraic theories I hope this gets across how the multi-sorted variant is not really so different. Now, if T\mathcal TT's objects weren't freely generated under finite products by any class of objects at all then you'd have something quite unusual-feeling, but that's not a case you're particularly likely to meet in practice.
Ah, @Kenji Maillard, I see we've given basically the same answer across the abelian/non-abelian divide--just a note that Zulip annoyingly insists on double dollar signs for Latex.
Letting T\mathcal{T}T be the category of non-empty finite sets, you find that AlgT\mathbf{Alg}\mathcal{T}AlgT is the category of Boolean algebras. Todd nicely explained this in his answer on MO.

I have 2 more problems with the notion of algebraic theory. Why the requirement of being finite product complete is exactly the right one for this notion ? Second question is in the snippet below in the example 1.10: why the right morphisms in SSS-sorted sets go contravariantly: a:k→na:k\to na:k→n ?
Snímek-obrazovky-2023-11-06-195900.png

I find it hard to answer your first question intelligently (I am not even convinced of what I am saying).

Functorial semantics (defining algebras as functors) is a very cool idea (thanks Lawvere) and the list of examples in this chapter shows you it encapsulates what lots of people consider to be algebraic. It led to many advances in categorical algebra and categorical logic, so I don't think anyone would say it is not the right notion.

Now, for why it is exactly right, one way I like to think of it is via [[Fox theorem]]. Informally, this theorem says that categories with finite products are preciely the places where you can copy and delete variables without problems. If you think about algebra as manipulating operation symbols and variables on paper (in a 1-dimensional syntax), in particular, copying and deleting variables as it pleases you, then you would expect the categories that embody the syntax for algebra are categories with finite products.

For the second question, there many ways to see this, I think unrolling what a product-preserving functor TS→Set\mathcal{T}_S \rightarrow \mathbf{Set}TS​→Set is and seeing it corresponds to a SSS-sorted set would be the most enlightening. In particular, you need to decompose any morphism in TS\mathcal{T}_STS​ as a composition of projections and pairings (what are they in TS\mathcal{T}_STS​) because these you know are preserved by the functor.

If you only look at the case S={∗}S= \{\ast\}S={∗}, hence TS=N\mathcal{T}_S = \mathcal{N}TS​=N, you see that a morphism t:n=∗0⋯∗n−1→∗0⋯∗m−1=mt: n = \ast_0\cdots \ast_{n-1} \rightarrow \ast_0\cdots\ast_{m-1} = mt:n=∗0​⋯∗n−1​→∗0​⋯∗m−1​=m is sent to a function An→AmA^n \to A^mAn→Am that takes (a0,…,an−1)→(a0′,…,am−1′)(a_0,\dots, a_{n-1}) \rightarrow (a'_0, \dots, a'_{m-1})(a0​,…,an−1​)→(a0′​,…,am−1′​) where each aj′a'_jaj′​ is equal to some aia_iai​. You can see this morphism ttt as mmm terms in the empty signature over nnn variables, so each of the mmm term is a single variable and aj′=aia'_j = a_iaj′​=ai​ if the jjj th term is the iii th variable.

Jan Pax said:

I have 2 more problems with the notion of algebraic theory. Why is the requirement of being finite product complete exactly the right one for this notion?

Because otherwise you get a different notion! :upside_down: If you want to use infinite products that's fine, but you get a different concept, sometimes called an infinitary algebraic theory. It can be very useful to restrict to products of order at most some cardinal κ\kappaκ. If you want to use finite limits that's fine too, but you get yet another notion, sometimes called a finite limits theory or essentially algebraic theory. If you want to use arbitrary limits, or limits of diagrams whose cardinality is at most some cardinal, that's also good. All these different notions are important and well-studied.

Jan Pax said:

Why the requirement of being finite product complete is exactly the right one for this notion ?

The operations we require in our categories tell us what the (co)domains of our function symbols are allowed to be. (For now, let's only allow equational axioms).

So for instance, finite product theories have some basic sorts, and then we allow function symbols from the products of those sorts to each other! For instance with groups multiplication is defined on G×GG \times GG×G, and for the 2-sorted theory of (ring, module) pairs, the action R×M→MR \times M \to MR×M→M is defined on R×MR \times MR×M. So the finite product structure is precisely what's used for the domains of our function symbols.

Contrast this with the finite limit theories (read: essentially algebraic theories) which allow partial operations, defined only on "nice" subsets of products of the basic sorts. For instance, in the definition of a category, composition is defined on {(f,g)∣dom(f)=cod(g)}⊆A×A\{ (f,g) \mid \text{dom}(f) = \text{cod}(g) \} \subseteq A \times A{(f,g)∣dom(f)=cod(g)}⊆A×A (where AAA is the set of arrows). Notice we need products and equalizers in order to build this domain, so we're using the full finite limit structure!

This story gets more complicated once we start adding relation symbols, but the basic premise that the operations on our (base) category correspond to allowable operations on our basic sorts remains useful intuition

@Ralph Sarkis Is it correct to say that your (a0,...,an−1)(a_0,...,a_{n-1})(a0​,...,an−1​) are exactly the standard variables (xσ(0),...,xσ(n−1))(x_{\sigma(0)},...,x_{\sigma(n-1)})(xσ(0)​,...,xσ(n−1)​) where each xix_ixi​ appears only once so that σ\sigmaσ is a permutation ? Otherwise there might occur some ambiguity in defining the morphism ttt. If there were more than 1 variable/term jjj th which is the more than 1 iii th variable then ttt will not be defined uniquely or correctly or undefined at all ? What is mind-boggling is this sentence: each aj′a'_jaj′​ is equal to some aia_iai​ and there might go something wrong in defining ttt ? I cannot resolve this.

These aia_iai​ and aj′a'_jaj′​ are elements of AAA, so the function defined by (a0,…,an−1)↦(a0′,…,am−1′)(a_0,\dots, a_{n-1}) \mapsto (a'_0, \dots, a'_{m-1})(a0​,…,an−1​)↦(a0′​,…,am−1′​) is ⟦t⟧\llbracket t \rrbracket[[t]], i.e. the semantics of ttt for some particular algebra N→Set\mathcal{N} \to \mathbf{Set}N→Set.

One way people represent terms is t:n→m=⟨t0,…,tm−1⟩t : n \to m = \langle t_0,\dots, t_{m-1} \ranglet:n→m=⟨t0​,…,tm−1​⟩ where each tjt_jtj​ is a term over nnn variables (we can call them x0,…,xn−1x_0, \dots, x_{n-1}x0​,…,xn−1​ ). Then the semantics of ttt takes an element of (a0,…,an−1)∈An(a_0,\dots, a_{n-1}) \in A^n(a0​,…,an−1​)∈An to the mmm -tuple whose jjj th coordinate is the value of tjt_jtj​ when the variables xix_ixi​ are assigned value aia_iai​.

Since terms are over the empty signature, they will be really simple. For instance ⟨x0,x0⟩:3→2\langle x_0, x_0 \rangle : 3 \to 2⟨x0​,x0​⟩:3→2 will be interpreted (in some algebra) as the function sending (a0,a1,a2)(a_0,a_1,a_2)(a0​,a1​,a2​) to (a0,a0)(a_0,a_0)(a0​,a0​).

Jan Pax said:

Why the requirement of being finite product complete is exactly the right one for this notion ?

To complement John's answer, my naive intuition is that, compared to finite limit theories, finite product theories have the nice property that reflexive coequalisers of algebras are well-behaved. To take the monad perspective (and restricting to nice categories), you probably know that forgetful functors from TTT-algebras to the base category create limits, but not colimits in general.
The colimits that are created are in fact the ones that TTT preserves (this is easy to prove).
In particular:

  • When TTT is finitary (which corresponds to finite limit theories, essentially because finite limits commute with filtered colimits), then all filtered colimits are created.
  • When TTT furthermore preserves reflexive coequalisers (which corresponds to finite product theories, essentially because finite products commute with sifted colimits, i.e., filtered colimits + reflexive coequalisers in nice categories), then reflexive coequalisers are also created.
